awd_titl_txt: University and Community College Collaboration for Mathematics and Biology Scholar Teacher Education
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the National Science Foundation's Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship program, University and Community College Collaboration for Mathematics and Biology Scholar Teacher Education will recruit undergraduate majors in mathematics and biology, and prepare them to teach at the high school level. The project will fund 45 scholarships over 5 years. In this project, Northeastern Illinois University will collaborate with Wilbur Wright and Harry S Truman Colleges and the Chicago Public Schools Offices of Math and Science. Faculty, coursework, and research will be shared across the Noyce learning community created by these four institutions, blending the experiences for the Noyce Scholars into a single, collaborative, multi-institutional program. 

In addition to building identities as collaborative scientists and educators, Noyce Scholars will benefit from a variety of supplemental activities, such as course-embedded research, guided summer research projects, and experiences with students and teachers in high-need schools.  Additional supports for Noyce scholars include informal education programs, mentoring by faculty and master-teachers in biology and math, training for peer leadership in PLTL (Peer Led Team Learning) groups, and content-specific new teacher induction and mentoring after graduation. The program will also sponsor scholars' attendance at professional conferences as well as presentations of their research with peers and faculty partners. Building on these efforts, the project will seek answers to three questions: 1) What is the relationship between Noyce Scholars' experiences in this STEM teacher preparation program, with its emphasis on collaboration, and community building in their school communities via their engagement in collaborative practices? 2) To what extent do pre-service collaboration practices facilitate Scholars' collaboration in other parts of their academic program and later in their teaching careers? 3) Do teacher quality and teacher retention in high-need urban schools improve as a result of such collaborations?

por.por_cntn:
The NOYCE program at NEIU started in 2017 with biology and math programs only. After a short time, we started implementing the Noyce program, and the secondary education program terminated its undergraduate science and math education programs. The secondary education program has shifted to a TLP/MAT program, adding chemistry, physics, and earth science majors. This change struggled us to recruit candidates for the Noyce program; however, we did not want to return the grant. Instead, we sought solutions through consulting with the program officer at NSF. We decided to continue the NOYCE program by offering Noyce scholarships to the TLP/MAT candidates. In the meantime, we continued recruiting from the undergraduate STEM majors until we graduated the candidates in the pipeline. We gladly provided 46.5 scholarships to 40 candidates. We want to summarize the significant outcomes of the NOYCE program below. 

  1.  Over the six years of the program, we recruited 40 scholars and provided 46.5 scholarships. Two scholars did not need financial support during their second semester; therefore, we stopped supporting these scholars financially. We used this fund  to recruit more candidates. One scholar needed help to start her student teaching during her term. She will complete her student teaching in the fall semester of 2023, but she will not be financially supported. 

  2. The program was initially designed to recruit only biology and math candidates; however, with the changes in the Noyce program, we also offered scholarships to chemistry, physics, and earth science majors. We recruited three chemistry, three physics, and one earth science majors. 

  3. The NOYCE program improved collaboration between the partnering community colleges and the programs at the College of Arts and Sciences, College of Education, and Chicago Public Schools(CPS). Through our partnership, we have ways to improve and increase the recruitment and retention of STEM majors and prepare them for the teaching profession. We decided to work on a teaching pipeline program at the partnering community colleges to recruit STEM majors to NEIU and recruit STEM teacher majors as early as they are sophomores. 

The other initiative is to open 4+1 accelerated pathways for those interested in teaching. So far, we have established it between the biology department and the secondary education program. The goal is to extend this accelerated pathway to chemistry, physics, and earth science. 

     4. To prepare secondary science and math teacher candidates effectively, the secondary education program and the Noyce program at NEIU have implemented various strategies to align with Culturally Responsive Practices (CRT) as one of its primary outcomes. By doing so, we ensure that future educators are better equipped to meet the needs of diverse student populations. Here are the critical components of our approach:

a) Community Service and Community Map Assignment: All candidates, including the NOYCE scholars, must engage in 20 hours of community service as part of their early foundational courses. It provides them valuable hands-on experience and fosters a deeper understanding of community dynamics. Additionally, candidates must complete a community map assignment during their clinical practicum, further promoting their awareness of local contexts.

b) Addressing Diverse Backgrounds: To help students from diverse backgrounds, teacher candidates are asked to prepare lesson plans and a unit plan that incorporates inclusive and culturally relevant teaching strategies. This approach ensures that students from various cultural backgrounds feel valued and represented in the classroom.

c) NOYCE Scholars and National Organizations: The NOYCE scholars are encouraged to become members of major national organizations, NSTA (National Science Teachers Association) and National Council of Teachers of Mathematics(NCTM). This membership offers access to valuable resources, professional development opportunities, virtual webinars focused on CRT practices, and networking within the education community.

d) Mentorship: Through the grant, we have learned that having a functional and working mentorship program is essential, and it must be established before the candidates graduate and start teaching. Most candidates, especially those from low-income families or diverse backgrounds, need emotional and academic support to graduate from the program and continue teaching after finishing their first year. The connection with the graduates and support must continue at least four years after they start teaching. We currently keep mentoring them and connecting with the other Noyce programs in the area to learn what strategies we can implement. 

5. The data collected from the candidates and graduates have shown that the candidates valued inviting experienced teachers to answer candidates’ questions and to listen to their experiences at the monthly meetups. They also endorsed the benefit of having a close connection with the Noyce faculty and other graduates. The majority think they are well prepared, but it would be much better if they had more experience with high-needs school environments and the needs of the students in these schools.
